displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So in this study there is a random allocation of the therapy and random also means that neither the physician which is me nor the patient which is you knows So it truly is random. And also the computer program flips the coin so to speak, you can only flip it once, you can’t continue to flip over and over until you get the condition you want Patient: Okay. Doctor: So option one is what we call observation. Your option two is the stereotactic radiotherapy, which I mentioned is called SBRT for short. that in order to make this trial a little more attractive to patients is designed ins such a way that the odds of getting the radiotherapy are twice as high as the odds of getting the observation. So in other words, you can think of it as a three-headed coin, there’s a one out of three chance that you’re gonna get the observation group. That’s about a thirty-three percent chance. And there’s a two out of three chance or sixty-six percent that you will get the stereotactic radiotherapy which most people on this trial want to get. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it. Patient: Yeah. I understand. Doctor: So here with the observation we are SBRT and you have a crossover. The crossover goes from the observation group to the therapy group. Okay. The crossover is basically gonna happen whenever or if the PSA level decreases by fifty percent of baseline. Patient: The baseline meaning my initial baseline – have to begin with or the baseline for this? Doctor: Baseline for this trial. Patient: The baseline for this would be somewhere around twenty-eight. Doctor: Correct.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That really made me feel good, for you, too, and for me. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because I was like “You’ve got to do that or I get derailed from what I have to do.” Patient: Right. Doctor: So he’s on it. Patient: He’s a terrific doctor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I’m really fortunate to have him as a doctor. Doctor: Yes, I agree. Patient: And I enjoy him as a personality- Doctor: Yeah.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But we know from looking at your scans, you have other areas that are starting to break through, we should try to do something. This is one option. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think a good one. It doesn’t mean that we won’t move onto, you know, pills – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - or other trials, or chemo, but this is a first step. Family Member: Right. Patient: So- Doctor: Yeah? Patient: That transfusion you’re talking about, you know, I read up on that way before I came to this hospital. Doctor: Um hum. Okay. Patient: It was a man that invented that transfusion and some other stuff they invented. What ever happened to him?

Family Member: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Doctor: That was Xtandi. So, tiredness. One of them has a low platelet issue. Like, you take it, and your platelets are gone. You stop it; the platelets come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that, Patient: No. Doctor: but it’s just, you know, we obsess about numbers. So, we’re like, “GAHHHH, where’d the platelets go?” And, that’s that. Appetite loss… Family Member: Ohhhh… (laughter) Doctor: Can occur which we can only pray for. Doctor: I would say that’s about it. I mean, in terms of what I really see people feeling bad about. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But the fatigue, you know, for somebody like you who is on the go constantly could be significant. Like, I don’t want to minimize that in the . You have

Patient: Don’t take the Ambien and the who again? Doctor: Restoril. This new sleeping pill. If I give you that… You know what, next time just bring all your Ambien pills and all that. Patient: Okay. I sure will. Doctor: That way, then I will give you the new sleeping pill prescription. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay but what I do in the meantime (laughs) Doctor: Well that’s why I was saying that well if there was somebody else with you, I’m concerned that you’re going to take both and it will be too much, it will zonk you out. Okay there’s nobody here with you even to tell for me to tell and the dangerous thing is you have your Ambiens at home. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you very well could make a mistake and take both, take the Ambien and the new sleeping pill. Patient: No I wouldn’t take the Ambien then. I’ll just throw them out. Doctor: You sure? Patient: Yeah I will pull them out.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -that showed probably no evidence of metastatic disease, okay, meaning no evidence of cancer that we can see. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The reason why I say probably- did you get these results on MyChart? Patient: Nuh-uh. Doctor: Okay, are you are you on MyChart? Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there. Doctor: Okay, that's fine. Let me print this out for you so that you can see what I'm talking about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll print both of them. Because the way that we, oh no there’s a lot of stuff coming out. So let me first sort of describe what we call like the stages of prostate cancer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: I’ll use the back of this. I think we talked about this last time, but I'll just, if I'm repeating myself and you get it, just say I remember all of this. So stages, so first you have what we call localized. Patient: Right.

Patient: We didn’t have to go to nobody. Doctor: We’re gonna make you the six million dollar man. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, and so yeah, and so and so this is gonna pass too. Doctor: Yes. We again, we’re just being really on top of it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So let me ask you this here because we talked about this in case it didn’t work. Doctor: Yes we did. Patient: Okay. Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when when when can we start taking the pill? Doctor: So what happens is I go through the insurance. They go through a third party vendor. So Diplomate, CVS Caremark, whatever one your insurance you know sends me to. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Creep up. Um hum. Doctor: We rechecked him. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then he’s got a couple of new spots in the bone which just happens to be in your skull. Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Which is, you know, no different than it is in the leg and what not but it’s a signal to us. Family Member: Oh. Exactly. Doctor: That something’s breaking through as in the shot itself is not enough. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So then you say, well, shoot, what, what could be my other options? Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then you say words like, chemotherapy. You say words like pills and other treatments. And they’re around.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Not only did it not work, but pause]] Mm, hmm? Patient: So, then we’ll go up front and get the appointment. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When we leave. Doctor: So about well six weeks would be about June eighteen, so sometime that week I need a PSA. Family Member: Okay. Patient: June eighteen for the blood work? Doctor: Yes, from C____ sometime that week. Patient: Yeah right. pause]] Family Member: Now are his bloodwork test results available online? Doctor: No. We don’t have it an outpatient patient portal yet.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Healthcare Professional: You need to have another (talking over each other) Doctor: Yeah and you need to have it as G____ just pointed out, you need to have an undetectable PSA. Healthcare Professional: Which he has. Doctor: Which you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know on face value suggests that there’s no additional… Patient: No PSA is not the best marker. Doctor: Exactly. Well it is a great marker but sometimes if the cancer cells that are there are in microscopic clusters… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …and they’re not organized enough… Patient: Right.

Patient: It’s up in here where it’s been. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, we can’t, you know. That part’s okay. Let me see this other skinny leg. Patient: Yeah, you’re right they’re skinny. Doctor: There’s no change there so that’s good but you think up here is swollen? Patient: Well, no, I don’t think it’s swollen. It’s just like a… Doctor: A little pain? Patient: Well, the muscle. Doctor: Yeah. Hang on. That’s not swollen. Okay, we got a plan. Patient: Like, huh. Doctor: We got a plan. Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night.

Patient: February Doctor: But not since you last saw me? Patient: Oh, no. But I did take iron then, but I haven’t taken it since. So. Doctor: Have you been thinking clearly? Any issues with your – just how you process things? Patient: No. (Clicking) Doctor: Anything new on your body today? Rashes? Skin changes? Patient: No. Doctor: Swelling? Bumps, Lumps? Patient: No. No. Family Member: Are those, uh, energy drinks that you see on TV problematic? I’m asking sort of for myself, too. Doctor: Uh. I mean they have a lot of calories in them, and so, uh, it’s more about why he’s takin’ them or Family Member: Oh, okay.

Patient: Yeah, I hear that. Doctor: You can check with Dr. G___ Any notes from us - So let’s get a hold of your results from your most recent lung scan and your visit from pulmonology as to what they say or their thinking is behind your gasping spells. It’s important. Ah, your ARV7 is positive. That suggests that the Enzalutamide may not work very long. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s likely in the near future that you’ll need new belly scan, abdominal scan, bone scan for us to more directly determine that the Enzalutamide is not benefiting you. So we tried to get your tissue sent for molecular testing but when we sent it, it wasn’t adequate for that sort of evaluation, so Dr. G__ may look at other options. Sometimes they can do another biopsy or do a blood test, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: but that’s not as good, but it’s something that’s easy, though. So once we’ve determined that your cancer has continued to grow, the standard therapy would be to move you to chemotherapy and if the name docetaxel based chemotherapy. Alternatively we’ve got two studies. I got rid of one as I wrote that. Patient: Right. Doctor: So the one is with Vitamin C. The one with the immune therapy. So I’m putting down an appointment for you to see me in a month. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You can check on my chart or you and Dr. G__ decide something earlier, or you need to see us earlier, the scans are made, you can see me earlier; that doesn’t mean I’m going to start you earlier. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you know if it’s sort of you would rather do chemo with us rather than closer to home or if one of these studies makes sense, then we will be available or just to check in to sort of see where you are with some of these decision processes. Vital signs Your my chart, you’re already hooked in. These are the medicines I think you’re taking.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean I could do that. You know I just want to make sure that if he’s you know ultimately if he’s going to get you chemotherapy and the closer you get to there and that can be given anywhere, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know we might just let that system do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If that’s where you’ve had them before for comparison sakes, then - Patient: I haven’t had chemo there. Doctor: But I’m talking scans. Patient: Scans. Yeah I’ve had scans at Hospital B and also Hospital C at O____ and also the Hospital A, so in M____. So you know it doesn’t make any difference really to me, yeah. Doctor: Great, I just want to make sure that they can be compared so that we can get a sense of what’s changed- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because if everything’s stable even though your PSA is going up, we might wait longer. If the pictures show more cancer and your PSA is higher Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Family Member: Well you couldn’t just do that as, like say you try it on those two guys, don’t you just try that with B__, knowing that there is still Germany, but um-? Doctor: Possibly. I have to figure how to get the immune therapy because it’s not an improved thing. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So there’s just some hoops to jump through. Family Member: Well, we’re kind of there now. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Like we really want to be treating this aggressively. Doctor: Well, I think if I was going to choose between those two things, and I had the means to choose between the two, I would choose the PSMA. Patient: Yes, I know. Doctor: Yeah. I mean this is really just antidotal for me for two patients. They’ve got other things in between that could have nothing to do with testosterone. We’re, we’re trying to make as much, we’ve got somebody interested in a small trial to test the idea, but I, I really, I wouldn’t be that confident. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Like you said, geez, which has the better chance? Family Member: No. I would still be doing the Germany thing, I just-
